snippet: Debate appears to have grown more heated over the value of the gaokao, the test at the end of high school that is believed to set the course of one’s life.
abstract: High school seniors in China, along with their families, await their scores on the gaokao, or college entrance examination; debate has grown over the value of the test, but in a country where education is so highly prized, the score is believed to set the course of one’s life; critics say the exam promotes the kind of rote learning that is endemic to education in China and that hobbles creativity.

byline.contributor: Christy Khoshaba contributed reporting from Kunming, China, and Jacob Fromer from Hong Kong. Mia Li and Shi Da contributed research.

lead_paragraph: Debate appears to have grown more heated over the value of the gaokao, the test at the end of high school that is believed to set the course of one’s life.

headline.seo: Burden of China’s College Entrance Test Sets Off Wide Debate
headline.main: Test That Can Determine the Course of Life in China Gets a Closer Examination
headline.print_headline: Test That Can Determine the Course of Life in China Gets a Closer Examination
